descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: At the heart of materials science & engineering the understanding, design and manipulation of "microstructure", particularly down to nano- and atomic-scale. Naturally, this requires deep understanding of morphology, crystallography, structure, chemistry and electronic structure and associated phenomena at those length scales. This course is about advanced electron-beam based analytical tools and techniques which form the foundation for analysis of materials down to atomic scale. It is meant to be a "practical" and experimentally-driven introduction to diverse analytical techniques and their relevance to emerging materials problems.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value:
Topics covered include: STEM imaging, EDS and EELS microanalysis and mapping,
microdiffraction and convergent beam electron diffraction (CBED). The course is
closely coupled with hands-on experimental laboratories consisting of about 5
labs. The course also requires experimental project in group of 2-3 students on
topics related to analytical TEM techniques.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Evaluation is based on homeworks, mid-term, lab work and final experimental
project report as well as presentation.
